questions.text: Identify the parasite
questions.solution:
Trophozoite shows ingested RBCs(trichrome stain). This feature known as erythrophagocytosis is specific for Entamoeba histolytica.

The ingested erythrocytes appear as dark inclusions. Erythrophagocytosis is the only characteristic that can be used to differentiate morphologically E. histolytica from the nonpathogenic entamoeba.

In these specimens, the parasite nuclei have the typical small, centrally located karyosome, and thin, uniform peripheral chromatin.

Option b: Entamoeba coli has no ingested RBCs. Mature cyst of E. coli has 8 nucleus.

Image shows stages of life E.coli

Option c: Entamoeba hartmanni has no ingested RBCs.

Related Pearl: Differential features of intestinal Entamoeba

Features E. histolytica E. coli E. hartmanni
   1. TROPHOZOITE
Size (µm) 12 - 60 20 - 50 4 - 12
Motility Active Sluggish Active
Pseudopodia Finger shaped, rapidly extruded Short, blunt, slowly extruded Finger shaped, rapidly extruded
Cytoplasm Clearly defined into endoplasm and ectoplasm Not defined Clearly defined into endoplasm and ectoplasm
Inclusion RBCs (erythro-phagocytosis), no bacteria Bacteria and other particles, no RBCs Bacteria and other particles, no RBCs
Nucleus Eccentric, not clearly visible in unstained films Visible in unstained films Not clearly visible in unstained films
Karyosome Small, central Large, eccentric Small, eccentric
Nuclear-membrane Delicate with fine chromatin dots Thick, coarse chromatin Coarse chromatin granules
   2. CYST   
Size (µm) 10 -15 10 - 30 5 – 10
Nuclei in mature cyst 4, central karyosome 8, eccentric karyosome 4
Glycogen mass Seen in uninucleate stage only Seen upto quadrinucleate stage Seen in uninucleate stage only
Chromatid bars 1-4, with rounded ends Splinter like with angular ends Numerous, irregular shape

questions.text: False about organism depicted in below image is

choices.text: Flagellate form in the infective stage

questions.solution:
Image depicts lifecycle of Naegleria fowleri which is a free living amoeba.

It is an amoeboflagellate i.e.trophozoites occur in 2 forms,amoeboid and flagellate form. Amoeboid trophozoite form is invasive stage of the parasite and the infective form of the parasite.

Option a: N. fowleri is a heat-loving (thermophilic) amoeba that thrives in warm water at low oxygen tension and is commonly found in warm freshwater (e.g. lakes, rivers, and springs) and soil.

Option b:

It exists in 3 forms:

  • Amoeboid trophozoite form:
    • With electron microscopy, vacuole appear to be densely granular in contrast to highly vacuolated body of amoeba and are called as amoebostomes
    • Amoeboid form is the feeding, growing, and replicating form of the parasite, seen on the surface of vegetation, mud, and water
    • It is the invasive stage of the parasite and the infective form of the parasite
  • Flagellate trophozoite form:
    • Bifflagellate form occurs when trophozoites are transferred to distilled water
  • Cyst:
    • Trophozoites encyst due to unfavorable conditions like food deprivation, dessication, cold temperature, etc

Option d:

Mode of infection: Human infection comes from water containing the amoebae and usually follows swimming or diving in ponds. 

Route of spread: The amoebae invade the nasal mucosa and pass through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges, and brain to initiate an acute purulent meningitis and encephalitis, called as primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM).

Incubation period: 2 days to 2 weeks.

C/F:

  • First symptom: Anosmia (during incubation period)
  • The disease advances rapidly, causing fever, headache, vomiting, stiff neck, ataxia, seizure, and coma
  • Cranial nerve palsies, especially of the third, fourth, and sixth nerves have also been documented
  • The disease almost always ends fatally within a week (average 5 days)

Diagnosis:

  • Wet mount of CSF shows trophozoites (Remember cysts are not found in CSF, brain)
  • Culture on non nutrient agar with E.coli

Treatment:

IV Amphotericin B and Rifampicin

questions.text: Identify the parasite
questions.solution:
Image shows trophozoite form of Giardia lamblia.

Features of Giardia trophozoite:

  • Tennis racket or heart shaped or pyriform shaped
  • Ventrally, it has a concave sucking disc, which helps in its attachment to the intestinal mucosa
  • Bilaterally symmetrical and possesses
    • 1 pair of nuclei
    • 4 pairs of flagella
    • Blepharoplast, from which the flagella arise (4 pairs)
    • 1 pair of axostyles, running along the midline
    • Two sausage­ shaped parabasal or median bodies, lying transversely posterior to the sucking disc
  • The trophozoite is motile, with a slow oscillation about its long axis, often resembling falling leaf

 

Cyst:

  • Infective stage
  • Quadrinucleate
  • Hyaline cyst wall

questions.text: Which of the following conditions predispose to infection with below given organism
questions.solution: Enhanced susceptibility to giardiasis is associated with blood group A, achlorhydria, use of cannabis, chronic pancreatitis, malnutrition, and immune defects such as 19A deficiency and hypogammaglobulinemia (IgA).

questions.text: False statement about the organism shown in the image given below is
questions.solution:
The above image shows Trichomonas. It has no cystic stage.

Identification features of Trichomonas vaginalis:

  • Pear-shaped or ovoid
  • Short undulating membrane reaching upto the middle of the body
  • It has four anterior flagella and fifth running along the outer margin of the undulating membrane, which is supported at its base by a flexible rod, costa
  • A prominent axostyle runs throughout the length of the body and projects posteriorly like a tail
  • The cytoplasm shows prominent siderophillic granules, which are most numerous alongside the axostyle and costa
  • Jerky or twitching type of mobility

The below image shows: 1-anterior flagella, 2-kinetosomes, 3-parabasal body, 4-costa, 5-parabasal fibers, 6-undulating membrane, 7-posterior flagellum, 8-hydrogenosomes, 9-axostyle, 10-nucleus, 11-pelta.

Obligate parasite - Organism cannot survive outside host

  • No cystic stage. Trophozoites are infective forms
  • Sexual transmission is the main route of infection. Other modes are fomites, babies during passage through infected birth canal
  • Affects squamous epithelium - Intracellular edema and so called chicken-like epithelium, is the most characteristic feature of trichomoniasis
  • Habitat: Vagina and cervix in female and urethra in males
  • Clinical features: Often asymptomatic in males. In females, it leads to pruritic vaginitis with greenish yellow discharge, strawberry mucosa and dysuria
  • Diagnosis: By wet mount microscopy of vaginal or urethral discharge, Culture (gold standard - Cysteine-peptone-liver-maltose (CPLM) medium and plastic envelope medium (PEM)), PCR, and by demonstration of antigen in vaginal smear by ELISA
  • Treatment: Metronidazole is the drug of choice and simultaneous treatment of both partners is recommended

questions.text: The below depicted test is used for
questions.solution:
The image shows string test/ entero test used for diagnosis of giardiasis.

Enterotest (String test)

  • It is a useful method for obtaining duodenal specimen
  • A coiled thread inside a small weighted gelatin capsule is swallowed by the patient, after attaching the free end of the thread in the cheek
  • The capsule passes through the stomach to the duodenum
  • After 2 hours, the thread is withdrawn, placed in saline, and is mechanically shaken
  • The centrifuged deposit of the saline is examined for Giardia

questions.text: Infective form of Trypanosoma cruzi depicted below is
questions.solution:
Metacyclic Trypomastigote is the infective form of Trypanosoma cruzi.

Identification of Trypomastigote forms:

  • Elongated, spindle shaped with a central nucleus.
  • The kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus (postnuclear kinetoplast) and situated at the posterior end of the body.
  • The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end.
  • This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of infected vertebrate.
  •  Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

Related Pearl: Various morphological stages of hemoflagellates

It is based on the arrangement of the flagella in relation to the position of the nucleus and its point of emergence from the cells.

Stage Morphological characteristics Seen in
Amastigote

Rounded or ovoid, without any external flagellum.

The nucleus, kinetoplast, and axial filaments can be seen.

The axoneme extends up to the anterior end of the cell

 Trypanosoma cruzi and Leishmania as the intracellular form in the vertebrate host.
Promastigote

Lanceolate in shape.

Antenuclear kinetoplast- kinetoplast is anterior to the nucleus near the anterior end of the cell, from which flagellum emerges.

There is no undulating membrane

 It is the infective stage of Leishmania, found in the insect vector as well as in cultures in­vitro.
Epimastigote

Elongated. 

Juxtanuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast placed more posteriorly, close to and in front of the nucleus.

The flagellum runs alongside the body as a short undulating membrane, before emerging from the anterior end.

It is the form in which Trypanosoma brucei occurs in the salivary gland of the vector tsetse fly and Trypanosoma cruzi in the midgut of the vector reduviid bug.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.
Trypo-mastigote

This stage is elongated, spindle-shaped with a central nucleus.

Postnuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus and situated at the posterior end of the body.

The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end.

This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of an infected vertebrate.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

questions.text: The given organism is vector for
questions.solution:
Image shows tse tse fly (Glossina species) which is the vector for African trypanosomiasis caused by Trypanosoma brucei.

Disease Causative organism Vector
African trypanosomiasis (Sleeping sickness) Trypanosoma brucei (Gambiense and rhodesiense) Tse tse fly
South American trypanosomiasis (Chaga’s disease) Trypanosoma cruzi Reduvid bug
Visceral leishmaniasis/Kala azar/ dum dum fever/ Black sickness Leishmania donovani Sandfly (Phlebotomus/Lutzomia)

Reduvid bug:

Sandfly:

questions.text: Identify the parasite whose infection is acquired through the bite of a tsetse fly.
questions.solution:
The image shows Trypanosoma brucei.

The most reliable method for differentiating the trypomastigotes of T. brucei and T. cruzi is by the size of the kinetoplast. T. brucei has a relatively small kinetoplast, while T. cruzi has a larger kinetoplast

Lesions seen in African sleeping sickness caused by Trypanosoma brucei are 

  • Chancre (at the site of bite of tse tse fly)
  • Cervical adenopathy in posterior triangle known as “Winter bottom sign.”

Stages of African sleeping sickness:

Stage I – no CNS involvement

  • Painless chancre at the site of bite of Tse tse fly.
  • Hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy, particularly in the posterior cervical region (Winterbottom’s sign)
  • Myocarditis
  • Hematological - anemia, moderate leucocytosis, and thrombocytopenia. High levels of immunoglobulins mainly immunoglobulin (IgM) are a constant feature.

Stage II – CNS invasion

  • Sleeping sickness, extrapyramidal symptoms, coma and death

questions.text: Following sign is seen in
questions.solution:
Image shows Romana’s sign i.e. unilateral painless edema of periocular tissues in the eye when conjunctiva is the portal of entry. This is a classical finding of the acute Chagas' disease.

'Chagoma' is the typical subcutaneous lesion occuring at the site of inoculation.

questions.text: Identify the lesion
questions.solution:
Image shows Chiclero ulcer also called as self healing sore of Mexico.

It is a specific lesion caused by L. Mexicana and is characterized by ulcerations in pinna.

Old world cutaneous leishmaniasis 

  • Organism - L. tropica and L.major
  • Vectors - P. surgenti and P. pappatasi
  • Lesion - Oriental sore or Delhi boil or Baghdad boil which begins as a raised papule, which grows into a nodule that ulcerates over some weeks.

New world mucocutaneous and cutaneous leishmaniasis:

  • Organism - L. brazilensis and L. mexicana.
  • Vector - sandfly of genus Lutzomyra.
  • Lesion: Chiclero ulcer by L. mexicana. Espundia is mucocutaneous involvement leads to nodules inside the nose, perforation of the nasal septum, and enlargement of the nose and lips and is caused by L. brasiliensis.

questions.text: The below given appearance is related to:
questions.solution:
In the given image, the black arrow points towards maltese cross, and yellow arrow points towards the ring form seen in Babesia.

Babesia, a genus of protozoan organisms that includes Babesia microti and Babesia duncani, are responsible for babesiosis. Ixodid ticks are the definitive host. Man is an intermediate host. Sporozoites are the infective form of humans.

The mode of infection is through a tick bite. Occasionally it can also be through blood transfusion.

The majority of the clinical symptoms are predominantly caused by hemolysis of the infected erythrocytes. The illness develops 1-6 weeks after the tick bite. It might be a mild, self-limiting, asymptomatic, or severe sickness that resembles malaria.
Malaise, exhaustion, high-grade fever (38°C to 40.6°C) with chills and sweating, myalgia, arthralgia, a dry cough, and anorexia are symptoms of acute illness.

Complications of acute babesiosis include renal failure, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and congestive cardiac failure (CCF).

On microscopic examination by Giemsa stain, Babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring form. The ring form is the most common and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit which differentiates it from P. falciparum. Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/Maltese crosses, which are pathognomonic of B. microti or B. duncani.

Treatment of B. microti infection

  • Mild infection is treated with atovaquone along with azithromycin
  • Severe infections are treated with azithromycin along with atovaquone or clindamycin along with quinine
  • Exchange transfusion is required in patients with high-grade parasitemia (≥10%), severe anaemia, and pulmonary, hepatic, or renal compromise.

Other Babesia infections are treated with a combination of clindamycin and quinine.

questions.text: The following cell cycle represents cell cycle of
questions.solution:
Ring form, accole form and banana shaped gametocytes are all features of Plasmodium falciparum.

Related Pearl: Difference between plasmodium species

Feature P.vivax P.ovale P.falciparum P.malaria
Discovered by Grassi & Feletti Stephens Welch Laveran
Erythrocyte preference Reticulocytes Reticulocytes All stages Old erythrocytes
Stages found in peripheral blood Trophozoite, schizonts, gametocytes As in vivax Ring form, accole form, gametocytes Band forms
Infected erythrocyte Enlarged pale with Schuffner’s dots Pear-shaped, fimbriated, Schuffner’s dots (Jame’s dots) Normal size, Maurer’s cleft Normal size, Ziemann’s stippling
Gametocyte Spherical, fills the cell Similar to but smaller than vivax Crescent, Banana shaped Similar to but smaller than vivax
Color of pigment Yellowish-brown Yellowish-brown Black Dark brown
Hypnozoites Present Present Absent Absent
Relapse Yes Yes No No
Average IP(days) 14 14 12 (shortest) 30 (longest)
Duration of erythrocyte cycle(hours) 48 (Benign tertian) 48 (ovale tertian) 48 (malignant tertian) 72(Quartan malaria)
Others       Nephrotic syndrome

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea. The given trophozoite stage is found in the stool sample. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the trophozoite stage of Balantidium coli. It is the only ciliated pathogenic protozoa infecting humans and is present in the large intestine as a commensal. It is the largest protozoan parasite of humans.

Trophozoite:

  • Large ovoid cell enclosed within a delicate pellicle showing longitudinal striations.
  • Has a narrow anterior end and a broad posterior end.
  • The cell has 2 nuclei—a large kidney-shaped macronucleus and a small micronucleus lying in its concavity.
  • 1 or 2 contractile vacuoles and several food vacuoles are present in the cytoplasm
  • There is a groove (peristome) at the anterior end that leads to the mouth (cytostome), and a short funnelshaped gullet (cytopharynx).
  • A small anal pore (cytopyge) is present posteriorly.
  • The cilia around the mouth are larger (adoral cilia)
  • Lives in the large intestine and feeds on cell debris, bacteria, starch grains, and other particles.
  • The trophozoite is actively motile due to the presence of short delicate cilia over the entire surface of the body. The invasive stage of the parasite is found in dysenteric stool.

Cyst:

  • It is spherical and measures 40–60 μm in diameter
  • A thick and transparent double-layered wall surrounds it
  • The cytoplasm is granular and has the macronucleus, micronucleus, and vacuoles present.
  • The cyst is the infective stage of B. coli and is found in chronic cases and carriers.

Balantidiasis is a zoonosis that is mostly asymptomatic. Pigs are the definitive hosts and man is an accidental host. Symptomatic disease presents with diarrhea or dysentery. The presence of intestinal ulcers and submucosal abscesses resembles amoebiasis.

The following image shows the trophozoite form of the Balantidum coli.

questions.text: The following lesion – Symmer’s clay pipe stem fibrosis is due to infection by
questions.solution:
Symmer’s clay stem fibrosis refers to periporatal fibrosis seen in infection with Schistosoma japonicum.

Other lesions:

  • Swimmer’s itch – mansoni and japonicum
  • Sandy patches and squamous cell carcinoma bladder – Schistosoma haematobium

questions.text: The given egg is of:
questions.solution:
Given egg is elongated with lateral spine. Hence it is an egg of Schistosoma mansoni.

Species differentiation of Schistosoma can be done based on the location of spine as follows.

  • Terminal spine: Schistosoma hematobium
  • Lateral spine: Schistosoma mansoni
  • Round with small lateral knob or Rudimentary spine: Schistosoma japonicum.

Related Pearl: Eggs of Schistosoma

questions.text: In the below given diagram which stage is absent in Schistosoma
questions.solution:
C represents stage redia which is absent in Schistosoma.

Life cycle of all trematodes:

Schistosoma differs in that it doesn’t have stage redia and metacercaria. Cercaria are the infective forms.

questions.text: Larva currens depicted below is a feature of
questions.solution: The term larva currens (meaning ‘racing larvae’) has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpigenous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis. These often follow autoinfection and start perianally.

questions.text: Identify the egg
questions.solution:
Egg has mucus plug at both sides. Hence it is an egg of Trichuris trichuria.

Egg of Trichuris trichuria:

It has a characteristic appearance.

  • It is brown in color being bile-stained.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.
  • It is barrel-shaped and about 50 μm long and 25 μm wide in the middle, with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum.
  • The plugs are colorless.
  • The egg floats in saturated salt solution.
  • When freshly passed, the egg contains an unsegmented ovum. At this stage, it is not infective for humans.
  • The fertilized female lays about 5,000 eggs per day.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a sheathed microfilaria with 2 nuclei at the tail which is characteristic of Brugia malayi.

Brugia malayi is endemic to Kerala (most common), Assam, Orissa, Madhya Pradesh and West Bengal.

Brugia malayi are smaller in size compared to microfilaria of W. bancrofti. It shows kinks and secondary curves. Cephalic space is longer and carries double stylets at the anterior end. The nuclear column appears blurred in Giemsa-stained films. The tip of the tail carries 2 distinct nuclei, one terminal and the other subterminal.

The below image shows the microfilaria of Brugia malayi.

Other options:

Option A: The microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti is sheathed with a pointed tail tip free of nuclei.

Option C: The microfilariae of Loa loa is sheathed with nuclei extending up to the pointed tail tip.

Option D: The microfilariae of Onchocerca volvulus is unsheathed with a blunt tail tip free of nuclei.

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology

questions.text: The following is caused by?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Loa Loa in the eye.

Loa loa filariasis is a skin and eye disease caused by the nematode worm Loa loa. Humans contract this disease through the bite of a deer fly or mango fly, the vectors for Loa loa. The adult Loa loa filarial worm migrates throughout the subcutaneous tissues of humans.

Subconjunctival migration of an adult worm to the eyes can occur frequently, and this is the reason Loa loa is also called the "African eye worm." 

They mature to adult worms in approximately one year, but sometimes up to four years. Adult worms migrate in the subcutaneous tissues at a speed less than 1 cm/min, mating and producing more microfilariae. The adult worms can live up to 17 years in the human host.

Differential diagnosis:

Onchocerciasis: The parasitic infection caused by nematode Onchocerca volvulus.

Ocular onhocerciasis may affect any part of the eyeball and may cause keratitis, iridocyclitis, choroiditis, glaucoma and optic neuritis and cause blindness (commonly known as ‘river blindness’).

Loa loa, on the other hand, mainly involves subcutaneous and subconjunctival tissues.

Onchocerca is usually smaller in size than Loa loa.

The pattern of microfilaraemia in onchocerciasis is opposite to that in Loa loa.

The microfilaria of Loa loa is usually found in day blood sample. It is known to migrate to the skin and other tissues at night, which causes itchiness commonly reported in ‘night guards’ infested with the disease.

The microfilariae of onchocerciasis migrate from tissues to the blood at night, which makes it ideal to take a blood sample at night. Both parasitic infections may coexist in endemic regions.

questions.text: The following image which shows coconut cake rectum is seen in
questions.solution: In heavy infection with Trichuris trichiura, sigmoidoscopy may show white bodies of worm hanging from the inflamed mucosa, the so called coconut cake rectum.

questions.text: Which of the following shows septate hyphae as depicted in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The microscopic image above shows septate hyphae with dichotomous branching at acute angles and a typical conidiophore is characteristic of Aspergillus. 

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients. This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is used for management.

Other manifestations include allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis where central bronchiectasis is usually seen. Aspergilloma and superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis are the other presentations.

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) stain is used. 

Other methods for diagnosis include the detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black. Yellow-green colonies are seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores. 

Invasive aspergillosis is treated with intravenous amphotericin B.

Other options:

Option A: Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Culture colonies are creamy-white and have a yeasty odor. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species, form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

The image given below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores:

 

Option B: Cryptococcus is an opportunistic fungus that is found worldwide as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings. Microscopy on Gram staining shows gram-positive round budding yeast cells. India ink preparation reveals capsulated budding yeast cells; capsules are prominent in this staining.

The image given below shows Cryptococcus neoformans stained with India ink. Note the prominent capsule.

 

Options C: Rhizopus and Mucor are zygomycetes that are responsible for mucormycosis. Non-septate, broad hyphae are seen on tissue samples stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

The image given below shows broad aseptate and irregularly-branched non-septate hyphae of Mucor.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: Sexual spore depicted in the below given image is
questions.solution:
Image shows sexual spore Basidiospore on basidium (base).

Option a: Ascospores are sexual spores in a sac or ascus.

Option c and d: Arthrospore and Blastospore are asexual spores.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on spore formation

It is classified into 4 types:

Glomeromycota:

  • Lower fungi with non-septate hyphae.
  • Asexual spores are called sporangiospores – within swollen sac-like structure called sporangia
  • Sexual spores are called zygospores and oospores

 

Ascomycota: 

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called ascospores - formed within a sac or ascus.

 

Basidiomycota:

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called basidiospores (on a basidium or base).

 

Deuteromycetes: (fungi imperfecti or hypomycetes) – sexual stages yet to be discovered.

questions.text: The below given image shows result of hair perforation test. The organism likely to show below given appearance is
questions.solution:
Image shows surface erosion of shaft caused by Trichophyton mentagrophytes.

Hair perforation test:

  • Done to differentiate Trichophyton rubrum from mentagrophytes.
  • A few strands of human hair are placed in a Petri dish with 20 ml of distilled water and autoclaved.
  • A few drops of sterile 10% yeast extract and a few fragments of the test fungus are added to the hair strands.
  • Incubated at 250C for 2-3 weeks.
  • Hair is removed and examined microscopically in a lactophenol cotton blue stained wet preparation.
  • T.mentagrophytes causes surface erosion of the shaft resulting in wedge shaped appearance of the shaft.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes with multiple circular, dry, scaly, itchy lesions on the scalp.  On further examination, it is seen that hair is involved but nails are spared. Scrapings from the lesion are inoculated and examined microscopically. Identify the dermatophyte based on the macroconidia seen in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of tinea capitis and the image showing large spindle-shaped macroconidia is a feature of Microsporum.

Dermatophytosis (commonly called tinea or ringworm) refers to infection of keratinized structures (the skin, hair, and nails) caused by a group of keratinophilic fungi, called the dermatophytes.

Dermatophytes are classified into 3 types:

  • Trichophyton infects skin, hair, and nails. The species include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc. Microconidia > Macroconidia
  • Microsporum infects only hair and skin but, not the nails. The species include M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. Macroconidia> Microconidia.
  • Epidermophyton infects only skin and nails, not hair. Floccosum is the only species in this genus. Only Macroconidia.

Clinical features of infection by Microsporum include:

  • Skin lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.
  • Hair lesions include kerion, scarring, and alopecia.

Diagnosis is established by clinical features, the use of Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as microscopic examination and culture characteristics.

Microscopic examination of material teased out from the fungal colony (culture mount) or material taken on cellotape (cellotape mount) is observed for identification of the species. It is observed for the presence and type of hyphae and conidia. Conidia (asexual spores) are of two types: small unicellular microconidia and larger septate macroconidia.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of macroconidia and microconidia of dermatophytes

Dermatophyte  

Macroconidia

Microconidia

Trichophyton

Thin-walled, pencil-shaped

Small unicellular

Microsporum

Multicellular, spindle-shaped

Scanty

Epidermophyton

Multicellular, pear-shaped, arranged in clusters

Absent

Trichophyton

 

Microsporum

 

Epidermophyton

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

Ivory or milky white

questions.text: Following copper penny bodies are feature of
questions.solution: Sclerotic bodies (Copper penny/Medler bodies) are features of Chromoblastomycosis also known as Fonseca’s disease or Pedroso’s disease or verrucous dermatitis.

questions.text: Spaghetti and meatballs appearance in KOH as shown here is characteristic of?
questions.solution:
Microscopy using KOH in Pityriasis versicolor shows hyphae and yeast cells that resemble spaghetti and meatballs

Pityriasis versicolor :

  • Wood lamp examination - yellow-green fluorescence
  • Fungal culture -  usually reported to be negative
  • Skin biopsy -  fungal elements may be seen within the outer cells of the skin (stratum corneum) on histopathology

questions.text: A person working in a farm developed multiple nodules along the lymphatics following rose thorn prick. The culture showed the following appearance. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
History of rose thorn prick, noduloulcerative lesions, and culture showing flower-like clusters of small conidia points towards the diagnosis of Sporotrichosis or rose gardener’s disease.

  • It is caused by the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.
  • Most commonly follows minor trauma like thorn prick etc in rose gardeners, forest workers, etc.
  • More common in Himalayan hilly areas (Himachal Pradesh).

Clinical features:

  • Nodules along the lymphatics which later undergo necrosis and ulceration.
  • Spreads along lymphatics to lymph nodes which become enlarged, suppurative and indurated.
  • Other rare types – osteoarticular, pulmonary, disseminated type.

Diagnosis:

  • Cigar-shaped asteroid bodies in H & E stained tissue sections
  • Culture – flower-like clusters of small conidia
  • Latex agglutination test
  • Skin test – delayed hypersensitivity to sporotrichin.

Treatment:

  • Cutaneous form – Potassium iodide (oral or topical)
  • Lymphocutaneous form – Itraconazole
  • Disseminated infection – Amphotericin B

questions.text: Given below appearance is a feature of yeast phase of which of the following organism?
questions.solution:
Yeast phase of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis occurs in tissues and in cultures at 37oC as large, globose, or oval cells with multiple buds encircling the mother cells, giving a mariner’s wheel or pilot’s wheel appearance.

Paracoccidioidomycosis (PCM) is a systemic fungal infection caused by the dimorphic fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis and Paracoccidioides lutzii. This disease predominantly affects individuals in rural areas of Latin America, particularly Brazil, Argentina, Colombia, and Venezuela.

The fungus can then spread through the lymphatic system and bloodstream to other organs. The immune response to the infection involves both cellular and humoral immunity. Granuloma formation is a hallmark of chronic PCM, with macrophages, lymphocytes, and giant cells surrounding the yeast cells. The disease has an insidious onset with pulmonary involvement, leading to a chronic productive cough, dyspnea, and hemoptysis. Mucocutaneous lesions in the mouth, nose, and pharynx are common and may be painful and ulcerative.

Treatment is with amphotericin B or itraconazole.

questions.text: Following dark green colonies on SDA agar are produced by:
questions.solution:
After 3-4 days incubation on Sabourand agar at 25-37 oC, the colonies have velvety to powdery appearance and are characteristically colored – A.fumigatus – dark green, A.niger – black and A.flavus – yellow-green.

Zygomycetes produce greyish white colonies.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with bloody nasal discharge, orbital swelling, and pain. The culture of Periorbital pus showed the following appearance. The most probable organism is
questions.solution:
The image shows septate hyphae showing dichotomous branching with typical conidiophore seen in microscopy which is characteristic of aspergillus infection.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: Following type of flagella is seen in
questions.solution:
Image shows peritrichous flagella seen in E.coli, Salmonella typhi and Proteus mirabilis.

Related Pearl: Types of flagella:

questions.text: In the given bacterial growth curve which phase shows involution forms
questions.solution:
Involution forms are seen in decline phase of bacterial growth curve.

  Lag phase Log/exponential phase Stationary phase Decline phase
Bacterial division No Yes Yes No
Death of bacteria No No Yes Yes
Total count (living plus dead cells) Flat Raises Raises Flat
Viable count (only living cells) Flat Raises Flat Falls
Special features

Preparatory phase – accumulation of enzymes and metabolites

Maximum size at the end of lag phase

 Small size, uniformly stained, metabolically active

Gram variable

Intracellular storage granules, sporulation, exotoxin and antibiotic production

 Involution forms are seen

questions.text: Identify the instrument
questions.solution:
Above image shows autoclave machine.

  • It is a method of sterilisation by moist heat.
  • High penetrative power.
  • Temperature - 1210C for 15 min
  • Spores of Bacillus stearothermophilus acts as control.

Hot air oven is a method of sterilization by dry heat.

  • Holding period of 1600C for 2 hours is used to sterilize glassware, swabs, glass syringes, scalpel, forceps, scissors.
  • Cutting instruments in ophthalmic surgery – 2 hours at 1500C.
  • Spores of Clostridium tetani act as control.

questions.text: Method of choice to sterilize the given instrument is:
questions.solution:
Isopropyl alcohol is the method of choice to sterilize clinical thermometer.

Related Pearl: Methods of sterilisation

Method of disinfection or sterilisation Material
Red Heat Inoculating wire loop, tip of forceps
Incineration Contaminated clothes, animal carcasses, plastics like polythene
Hot air oven Glasswares, scalpels, forceps, cutting instruments, test tubes
Inspissator Heat labile culture media containing egg, sugar or serum
Autoclave Culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut
Isopropyl alcohol Clinical thermometers, stethoscopes, probes
Methyl alcohol Fungal spores

Beta propiolactone/

formaldehyde

 Fumigation of operating theatres, wards and labs
2% gluteraldehyde Cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, fibre-optic endoscopes, plastic ETT, face masks
Plasma sterilisation Arthroscopes, urethroscopes
Ethylene oxide Heart lung machines, respirators, dental equipments, sutures, books, clothings
Filtration (Seitz filters) Bacterial vaccines, intravenous solutions
5% cresol, hot air oven Sharp instruments

Ionising radiation

(Cold air sterilization)

 Catgut, swabs, plastic, syringes, needles, gloves, catheters, grafts
Chlorhexidine Disinfecting surgeon’s hands prior to surgery
Iodophor Disinfecting surgical site prior to surgery
70% ethanol Disinfectant skin prior to venepuncture or immunisation
Thiomersal Preservative in vaccine
Silver sulfadiazine Cleanse burn wounds
Hypochlorite Cleanup of blood spill from a patient with hepatitis B or C
Hydrogen peroxide Cleanse wounds

questions.text: Image shows growth of Salmonella typhi in Wilson and Blair media. It is a type of
questions.solution:
Wilson and Blair media is a type of selective and indicator media.

Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces black metallic sheen in Wilson and Blair media which indicates the growth of Salmonella. It is an example of indicator media. It is a selective media as well because inhibiting substances are added to inhibit the growth of unwanted bacteria.

It is a differential media as well; It brings out different characters of bacteria. 

On the Wilson-Blair medium, S. typhi forms large black colonies, with a metallic sheen. S. paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

Another example of indicator media is McLeod’s media for Diphtheria bacilli.

Examples of selective medium include Deoxycholate media for Salmonella and Shigella, LJ media for tubercle bacilli.

Examples of differential medium include MacConkey’s media for differentiating lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters.

questions.text: Following diagram depicts
questions.solution:
Transfer of portion of DNA from one bacteria to another by bacteriophage is referred to as transduction.

Option a: Transformation refers to transfer of genetic information through the agency of free DNA.

Option c: Conjugation refers to a process where male/donor mates with female/recipient and transfers genetic elements through conjugation tube.

questions.text: Which of the following is the contribution of scientist in the below given image

choices.text: First to observe and report bacteria

questions.solution:
Image is of Louis Pasteur who discovered vaccine for rabies.

Contributions of Louis Pasteur (Father of microbiology):

  • Disproved theory of spontaneous generation
  • Formulated germ theory
  • Discovered pasteurization, sterilization techniques, fermentation
  • Coined the term vaccine and microbiology
  • Vaccine for rabies, chicken pox, cholera and anthrax

Option a: Anthrax bacilli was discovered by Robert Koch

Contributions of Robert Koch (Father of Medical microbiology)

  • Discovered tubercle bacilli, anthrax bacilli, Vibrio cholera
  • Staining techniques
  • Solid culture techniques

Option c: Small pox vaccine was discovered by Edward jenner.

Option d: First to observe and report bacteria was Antony Van Leeuwenhoek

questions.text: You are a microbiology resident teaching the staining technique shown in the image below to medical students. What is the order of the steps to be followed in this technique?

choices.text: Crystal violet, iodine solution, decolorisation, carbol fuchsin
Crystal violet, decolorisation, iodine solution, carbol fuchsin
Carbol fuchsin, iodine solution, decolorisation, crystal violet
Crystal violet, carbol fuchsin, iodine solution, decolorisation

questions.solution:
The given microscopy image shows Gram staining, and the order of Gram staining is as follows:

  • Primary staining with para-rosaniline dye (crystal violet, methyl violet, or gentian violet)
  • Application of dilute iodine solution
  • Decolorisation with an organic solvent (ethanol, acetone, aniline)
  • Counterstaining with the dye of contrasting color (carbol fuchsin, safranine, neutral red)

The suggested theories in Gram staining are that a gram-positive organism retains the primary basic dye due to its acidic protoplasm. Also, a thick peptidoglycan layer present in gram-positive bacteria helps in retaining the dye-iodine complex. The lipid content in gram-negative bacteria is very high, which makes it permeable to secondary dye after decolorization with organic solvents like acetone.

Therefore, gram-positive bacteria retain the primary stain and appear violet. Gram-negative bacteria appear red because they get decolorized and take up the counterstain.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: False about immunoglobulin depicted in the below given image is
questions.solution:
Image shows pentameric IgM antibody.

IgM doesn’t cross the placenta. It is the earliest immunoglobulin synthesized by the fetus. Hence its detection is useful in the diagnosis of intrauterine and congenital infections.

It is mostly intravascular

It is the first to appear following infection and disappears early. Hence indicates recent infection – primary immune response.

Examples include – ABO antibodies, antibodies to typhoid O antigen, rheumatoid factor.

questions.text: A man suffered from a crush injury and presented with severe pain, soft tissue crepitus, discoloration, and bullae in the affected area. The discharge from the affected site was positive for Nagler's reaction. What type of serological test is Nagler's reaction?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens. Nagler’s reaction done here is an example of neutralization test.

The α-toxin of C. perfringens has lecithinase activity. When C. perfringens is grown on a media containing egg yolk with the α-antitoxin spread on one half of the plate, colonies on the other half without the antitoxin will be surrounded by a zone of opacity. There will be no opacity around the colonies on the half of the plate with the antitoxin due to the specific neutralization of α-toxin. This is known as Nagler's reaction.


Gas gangrene is caused most often by Clostridium perfringens species. Microscopically it is a gram-positive bacteria without spores. It is an anaerobe. Sample collection and transport are to be done in Robertson's cooked meat medium. It grows well on Blood agar showing target hemolysis. The reverse CAMP test is positive with a hemolysis arrow pointing toward the Clostridial streak. Nagler's test is a quick test to show the presence of Clostridium.

Related Pearl: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

  • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax
  • Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique
  • VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)
  • Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)
  • Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

  • Widal test- typhoid
  • Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever
  • Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis
  • Coombs test
  • Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis
  • Anti streptolysin O test

Complement fixation test:

  • Wasserman reaction(syphilis)
  • Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

  • Schik test for diptheria
  • Anti streptolysin O test
  • Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text: All of the following organism shows the following type of growth in culture media except
questions.solution:
The image shows swarming type of growth on blood agar. Swarming growth on culture media is exhibited by

  • Gram positive bacilli
    • Clostridium tetani
    • Bacillus cereus
  • Gram negative bacilli
    • Proteus mirabilis
    • Proteus vulgaris

questions.text: An 18 year old female presents with severe headache and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilloedema and nuchal rigidity was present. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
History and physical examination findings are suggestive of meningitis.

The given image shows intracellular gram negative diplococci i.e. Neisseria meningitidis.

Option A: Haemophilus influenzae type B is a gram-negative bacillus. In CSF, long bacillary filamentous forms predominate.

Option C: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram positive, capsulated, flame shaped or lanceolate shaped diplococci.

Option D: Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus.

questions.text: Factor responsible for given appearance of pneumococcal colonies is
questions.solution:
Autolysin is responsible for draughtsman or carom coin appearance of pneumococcal colonies.

Streptococcus pneumoniae also contains within itself the enzymatic ability to disrupt and to disintegrate the cells (bacterial peptidoglycan). The enzyme is called an autolysin. The major pneumococcal autolysin, N-acetylmuramoyl-L-alanine amidase is also known as LytA amidase. The physiological role of this autolysin is to cause the culture to undergo a characteristic autolysis that kills the entire culture when grown to stationary phase.

questions.text: Given appearance on culture is shown by
questions.solution:
Given image shows box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance of Bacillus anthracis.

Other appearances of anthrax bacilli:

M’Fadyean’s reaction – Shows capsule when stained with polychrome methylene blue

Frosted glass appearance on agar plate

Medusa head appearance on microscopy

Inverted fir tree appearance on gelatin slab

String of pearls reaction on solid media containing penicillin.

questions.text: Which organism shows the below-depicted phenomenon when incubated with staphylococcus aureus on blood agar?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the phenomenon of satellitism which is exhibited by Haemophilus influenzae when incubated on blood agar along with Staphylococcus aureus.

H. influenzae requires growth factors V and X that are present in the blood.

  • Factor V  is a nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), a coenzyme, and is heat labile.
  • Factor X is hemin. It is required for cytochrome synthesis and the function of enzymes like catalase and peroxidase. It is heat stable.

Satellitism is seen when S. aureus is streaked across a plate of blood agar on which H. influenzae has been inoculated. After overnight incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae will be large and well-developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus and smaller when they are farther away from the streak. This is due to the release of factor V by lysis of RBCs mediated by S. aureus. Thus factor V is present in high concentrations near the streak. The Hemophilus colonies become progressively smaller further away from the streak because the factor V concentration becomes less. 

The given image shows satellitism on blood agar.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with lesions on his face as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism of this boy's condition.
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a boy presenting with small pearly white umbilicated wart-like lesions with a characteristic dimple at the center  is suggestive of infection by Molluscum contagiosum virus, which belongs to the pox virus family.

Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limiting viral disease of the skin caused by molluscum contagiosum virus. The age of peak incidence is between 2 and 5 years. In children, it is mainly caused by the type I molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV-1). There is a relatively higher incidence of MCV‐2 type in adults and HIV infection. Sexually transmitted molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.

It has an incubation period of 2 weeks to 6 months. The lesions are shiny, pearly white, hemispherical, umbilicated papules that may show a central pore. These may enlarge slowly. Widespread and refractory lesions are seen most commonly in HIV or patients on immunosuppressive therapy. 

It is characterized by the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies called Henderson-Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies. Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon is seen i.e., new lesions develop along a line of trauma.

The diagnosis is usually clear when multiple lesions at different stages of evolution are seen and the classical umbilicated papule is observed. Diagnosis can be confirmed by direct microscopy, histopathology, or molecular analysis.

Treatment is usually not required, and lesions are likely to resolve spontaneously. Stimulation of the immune response can be done after destructive or inflammatory therapies with salicylic acid, trichloroacetic acid, and imiquimod. Cryotherapy when done needs to be repeated at 3-4 week intervals. Extensive lesions are treated with an antiviral agent like cidofovir.

questions.text: A child is brought with symptoms of fever and sore throat.  The following findings are noted on examination of the oral cavity, palms, and soles. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
A child presenting with symptoms of fever and sore throat with blisters in the mouth, palms, and soles points to the diagnosis of hand-foot-and-mouth disease. The most likely etiological agent is the Coxsackie virus.

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease is an exanthematous fever that commonly affects children below 10 years of age and is caused due to infection by the coxsackieviruses, with the A16, A9, and B 1-3 serotypes most commonly implicated.

The incubation period is around 5-7 days and children usually present with symptoms of low-grade fever, sore throat, and malaise. An early feature of the illness in adults is stomatitis, characterized by painful blisters in the mouth. These blisters may break down to form ulcers. Greyish oval vesicles may be observed on the palms and soles and these are more likely to be seen in children. They fade after 2–3 days.

Laboratory diagnosis involves the isolation of the virus from the lesions or feces and inoculation into suckling mice. Due to the presence of several antigenic types, serodiagnosis is not useful, as is tissue culture. Management is supportive with intravenous immunoglobulin reserved only for severe cases.

Other options:

Option B: Epstein-Barr virus causes infectious mononucleosis. It commonly affects young adults and manifests as fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy and mild, transient rash.

Option C: Herpes simplex virus type 2 is responsible for the majority of genital herpes infections. It is a venereal disease that can give rise to vesiculo-ulcerative lesions affecting the genitalia.

Option D: Varicella-zoster virus can cause chickenpox and herpes zoster. The former usually affects children and presents as a rash that is centripetal in distribution, mainly involving the trunk and sparing the distal parts of the limbs. Herpes zoster is usually observed in adults after the fifth decade of life and the rash is unilateral and confined to the area supplied by a single sensory ganglion

questions.text: Disease not transmitted by given vector is
questions.solution:
Image shows vector Aedes aegypti mosquito which transmits chikungunya, dengue and yellow fever.

Culex is a vector for Japanese encephalitis.
